Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Carty Mr. Carty

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O.J. Flanagan Mr. O.J. Flanagan

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Jack Lynch
Speaker.P: There is a 20 per cent decrease in imports.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L'Estrange Mr. L'Estrange
Speaker.P: Labour had not much to say about it at its recent Congress.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Telephone Directory.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Ryan Mr. Ryan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs if he is aware that many current telephone directories have fallen asunder because of the inadequacy of binding; and that many telephone subscribers have unsuccessfully applied to his Department for replacement copies and have been informed that no spare copies are available; when the next issue of the directory will be available; and if he will take steps to ensure that it is made up in a form which with reasonable use will last until the next succeeding directory.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Childers) Erskine Hamilton Childers

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Sligo Post Office.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gilhawley Mr. Gilhawley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs if it is the policy of his Department to close sub-post offices in rural areas; if he is prepared to recommend the re-opening of Killaville post office, County Sligo, which was closed following the death of the sub-postmaster; and if he will ensure that a public telephone and an efficient letter-box collection will be maintained there.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Childers Mr. Childers
Speaker.P: Rural sub-post offices are closed only when insufficient use is made of them to warrant their retention. The re-opening of the sub-post office at Killaville would not be justified because the amount of post office business transacted there was trivial. The provision of public telephone facilities at Killaville would not be warranted having regard to the small use made of the post office telephone prior to its closure. A letter-box has been provided and the collection service has not been affected by the closure of the office.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Price of Dublin Building Land.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Leary Mr. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government whether he is aware that the price of building land in Dublin is now a major element in the rising cost of houses; and whether he proposes to take any action in regard to this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: I am aware that because of the number of houses provided in the Dublin area, totalling about 23,000 in the past 5½ years, the pressure on the supply of serviced land for building has resulted in increased land prices.

This increase, together with other increases such as the increase in labour costs, which account for up to half of the cost of building a house, and the increase in the cost of materials, has resulted in the rising cost of houses to which the Deputy refers.
As to the final part of the question, I would refer the Deputy to my reply to a question on the same subject on 13th April last.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Does the Minister consider it a satisfactory situation that land for building purposes is now being sold in the environs of Dublin city for £5,000 an acre? Does the Department propose to do nothing about this extraordinary price for building land?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: I do not consider the present price which is being obtained in some instances for land to be satisfactory, and my Department have done something about it, as I said on 13th April last. These measures have had a certain effect.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Dunne Mr. S. Dunne
Speaker.P: Will the Minister take it from the speculative builders who grab it up and inflate prices?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L'Estrange Mr. L'Estrange
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that speculators have bought land from owners who could not get planning permission to build houses on it, and that immediately the speculators bought it, they were able to get planning permission to build houses, and in some instances they got as much as 1,000 per cent profit on the land?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: The Deputy cannot produce any evidence of such things happening. I am quite certain he cannot. He can say things like that at chapel gates in Limerick but he cannot produce evidence of any single instance in which this happened. It is a product of the Deputy's imagination.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L'Estrange Mr. L'Estrange
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that one speculator bought land for £23,000? He got permission from the Department to build houses on it. He sold it for £75,000 and gave a £10,000 subscription to the Fianna Fáil Party. That cannot be denied. It is a well-known fact.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: The Deputy only invents that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that in a situation where land is going even near the price of £5,000 an acre, something drastic must be done? Would he agree that his Department have been sitting on the fence in this matter?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: I would not agree. Since March last the Dublin authorities have acquired sufficient land to accommodate over 5,000 dwellings and with the land they have available they can now provide not less than 8,000 sites within two years in the Dublin area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Belton Mr. P. Belton
Speaker.P: Is all the land the Corporation have serviced at the moment or will it be serviced in the future? Can houses be built on it at the moment?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: Some of it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Belton Mr. P. Belton
Speaker.P: Is it not true that very little is serviced?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: Not “very little.”

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Belton Mr. P. Belton
Speaker.P: Ten per cent of it is not serviced.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: And on that that is not serviced building can be allowed so that it will be completed at the same time as the services are provided.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Belton Mr. P. Belton
Speaker.P: Surely Templeogue is the only place where that is happening? It is not on the north side as yet.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: It can happen in different places.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Dunne Mr. S. Dunne
Speaker.P: Did the Minister ever hear of gracious living? What about Castleknock at £8,000 per house?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: I am aware that all houses are not sold at the same price.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: Is the Deputy worrying about these people? I am not. I am concerned with small houses. I am concerned with keeping down the price of small houses and others who are able can pay whatever price they like. I do not care.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: If you cannot maintain a ceiling price on land, the price of houses will go up in the long run.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: I am taking the necessary steps to make sites available for modest-priced houses. The Labour Party never did anything about this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: The Labour Party never showed any concern until they heard me talking about it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mullen Mr. Mullen
Speaker.P: The Minister has a chance to do something about it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Dunne Mr. S. Dunne
Speaker.P: The Minister is just covering up. Do not think you can cod the people as easily as that.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Rehousing Proposals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Office Building in Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government whether his Department intend taking any action to curtail the amount of office building in Dublin and to direct resources so employed into the provision of houses.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: It is a matter for Dublin Corporation as planning authority to determine the policy for the accommodation and control of office development in their area. The draft development plan for the city which was recently prepared by the Corporation includes a number of provisions in this regard.
It cannot be assumed of course that the discouragement of office building in Dublin by whatever means, would necessarily divert resources to the provision of housing.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that certain Government Departments have given an impetus to this tendency to build more office blocks in Dublin and that people have invested money in this very profitable undertaking in the short term? It follows that if we could divert the resources at present going to office buildings to the provision of housing by cutting the profit rate, a great deal could be done to relieve the situation. Is the Minister aware that certain Government Departments have helped on this tendency towards making office buildings more profitable?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: I am aware that certain Government Departments have taken more suitable office accommodation, but there is no question of the Government or any Government Department encouraging this expensive office building.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that a big element in the present high returns in profits for office building in Dublin is the part Government Departments have played in taking over such office buildings?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Liberty Hall.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: The most obvious example of that—I see it every day; I have only to look out of my window, and I do not think there are any Government Departments in it——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: The only example there is in Dublin of a purely prestige office building is outside my office window in the Custom House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: And the workers own it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: That is the only one that does not pay its way. It is so expensively constructed as to be completely uneconomical. That is the only organisation I know of which had sufficient money to build a purely wasteful building, which has not even got the virtue of being an economic undertaking.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: If the Minister wishes to cover up his action by cheap jibes of that nature——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: It is not supported, so far as I know, by Government Departments.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Cormac Breslin
Speaker.P: Question No. 11, to the Minister for Labour.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: If it were possible for us to have stopped that office building, as this question suggests, there was no guarantee that the money would have been diverted to the provision of houses.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Hospitals Trust Limited.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he is aware that in the employment of Hospitals Trust Limited, which is established under permit from the State, the principle of free association as defined by the International Labour Organisation is denied in so far as the trade union of which certain employees are members is refused recognition and the right to represent and negotiate on their behalf; and that on two occasions the Labour Court recommended that the management should negotiate with the trade union but that the management refused; and whether he is prepared to advise Hospitals Trust Limited that in so far as this State has ratified Convention No. 87 (Freedom of Association and the Right to Organise) the Government require them to observe such Convention, that otherwise the Government must reconsider the conditions governing the permit under which Hospitals Trust is enabled to conduct public sweepstakes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Dr. Hillery) Patrick J. Hillery
Speaker.P: The assertion in the first part of the Question has not been proved.
I am aware of the two Labour Court Recommendations mentioned. My attitude to these is the same as it is to all Labour Court Recommendations and it is that I strongly favour their acceptance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: Having regard to the Minister's responsibility for good industrial relations, does he think it conducive to good industrial relations that 250 workers who are members of a reputable trade union are not recognised by this institution which operates under Government permit?

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Hillery Dr. Hillery
Speaker.P: The Labour Court have made recommendations and these should be accepted, as I think that in every case Labour Court recommendations should be accepted.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: Would the Minister be good enough to convey that opinion to the Directors of the Irish Hospitals Trust?

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Hillery Dr. Hillery
Speaker.P: I am sure they will hear about it once I have said it here.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cosgrave Mr. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: Is it not a fact that the bulk of the staff are satisfied with the standards laid down? There is nothing anti-trade union in this. It is an Irish industry established by Irishmen and should not be sabotaged.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. James Tully Mr. James Tully
Speaker.P: If the Leader of Fine Gael has nothing better to say about workers who are looking for decent conditions, he should keep his mouth shut.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cosgrave Mr. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: The bulk of the workers are satisfied.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: They are not. They are denied their right to free association in a trade union. They are members of what is termed a house association, but that is not a trade union.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Cormac Breslin
Speaker.P: Order. The Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Hillery Dr. Hillery
Speaker.P: In answer to Deputy Cosgrave, the right of free association exists in so far as these people in this company are organised in a house association and those who want to be organised in a trade union are so organised.

In reply to Deputy S. Dunne's assertion that Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil are joined together in this, I would like to read now a reply given by Deputy Corish, on behalf of Deputy Everett, who was Minister for Justice at the time, to the very same question:

I have no function with regard to the implementation of the provisions of either the convention or recommendation referred to. The powers of the Minister for Justice to make modifications in a scheme for a sweepstake submitted to him under Section 6 of the Public Hospitals Act, 1933, relate only to such matters as are dealt with in the section. The question of staff control or representation is not one of these matters.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Dunne Mr. S. Dunne
Speaker.P: Give us the date of that.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Hillery Dr. Hillery
Speaker.P: 26th July, 1956.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: Would the Minister say when the Labour Court recommendations were made and will he further say whether or not this house association is registered as a friendly society with the Department of Industry and Commerce or as a trade union with his own Department?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Dunne Mr. S. Dunne
Speaker.P: Would the Minister say if the question to which he referred was a “planted” question?

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Hillery Dr. Hillery
Speaker.P: The reason I read out that answer was that Deputy Corish asked that I should bring pressure to bear on the Hospitals Trust to enforce this recommendation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: I said the Minister should consider the terms of the permit.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Hillery Dr. Hillery
Speaker.P: And I did not answer that because the matter is proper to the Minister for Justice; but Deputy Corish knows the answer already because he gave it himself. One of the recommendations of the Labour Court was made in 1950 and one in 1967. The house association is not registered as a trade union. Neither is it registered as a friendly society.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: There are 250 members of a trade union in this institution, which caters for approximately 930 regular staff. That means that nearly 30 per cent are members of a trade union. Surely they should not be denied recognition for the purpose of negotiation?

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Hillery Dr. Hillery
Speaker.P: I agree. The Labour Court recommended that they should be recognised and I think all Labour Court recommendations should be accepted, including this one. I said the association is neither a friendly society nor a trade union, but, being an excepted body, it has the right to negotiate under the Trade Union Act of 1942.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: Is there any legal definition of “house association”?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. James Tully Mr. James Tully
Speaker.P: A bosses' union.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Hillery Dr. Hillery
Speaker.P: The 1941 Act made provision for excepted bodies and the 1942 Act provided that an excepted body would cover any body which represented people working for one employer and who only spoke on behalf of their own fellow employees.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: When there is an official trade union, does this quite cover the situation? I suggest it does not cover the situation in which there are a recognised trade union and a house association existing side by side and the management refuses to negotiate with the trade union and negotiates only with the house association.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Hillery Dr. Hillery
Speaker.P: The question was whether this association has the right to negotiate: it has.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cosgrave Mr. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: Is it not a fact that the Labour Court found that the choice between a house association or a trade union organisation was a matter for the employees?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: It is a phoney association. It is not a trade union.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cosgrave Mr. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: If that is so, why are there 900 members in it?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: Because, if they were not, they would not be kept in the Irish Hospitals Trust.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cosgrave Mr. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: They are satisfied with the conditions in an Irish firm giving good employment and helping the hospitals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Larkin Mr. Larkin
Speaker.P: The recommendation of the Labour Court was a straight recommendation, without qualification of any kind, that the union should be recognised. Possibly Deputy Cosgrave has some interest in this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cosgrave Mr. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: None whatever, except that I do not want to see it sabotaged for theoretical reasons.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: Who wants to see it sabotaged?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Dunne Mr. S. Dunne
Speaker.P: How could one sabotage a multi-million dollar institution?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cosgrave Mr. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: An institution maintained by Irishmen for the benefit of Irishmen.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Cormac Breslin
Speaker.P: Order. I am calling Question No. 12, to the Minister for Finance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Larkin Mr. Larkin
Speaker.P: Was it a specific recommendation that the Hospitals Trust should negotiate, without any qualification whatsoever?

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Hillery Dr. Hillery
Speaker.P: The text of the recommendation is:
The Court recommends that the company should concede to the union the right to negotiate on behalf of its members in the company's employment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Larkin Mr. Larkin
Speaker.P: Is that not in accordance with the ILO Convention?

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Hillery Dr. Hillery
Speaker.P: That is the second recommendation. The first recommendation——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. James Tully Mr. James Tully
Speaker.P: We are talking about the first recommendation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Larkin Mr. Larkin
Speaker.P: It is the ILO Convention. The right to representations is also contained in the Convention as well as the right of association.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Hillery Dr. Hillery
Speaker.P: That, I think, could be argued.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Dunne Mr. S. Dunne
Speaker.P: There is a third opinion in the organisation, of course.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Cormac Breslin
Speaker.P: Order. The Minister for Finance.

MainHeading.RHead: - PAYE Tax on Social Welfare Stamps
MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - PAYE Tax on Social Welfare Stamps.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he will take steps to end the system of charging PAYE tax on the cost of social welfare stamps included in the gross earnings of employees.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Under existing law, the proportion of a contribution paid by an employed contributor or by a voluntary contributor under the Social Welfare Acts which is attributable to widow's pension, orphan's allowance and old age pension is, as the Deputy is no doubt aware, allowable as a deduction for income tax purposes. MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dublin Garda Motorcycle Patrols.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Briscoe Mr. Briscoe
